title: The Character Blueprint
subtitle: Expanding Class Fundamentals
description:
# Object-Oriented Programming: Classes Deep Dive

üé≠ Welcome to the world of **Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)**!

## What are Classes?

Classes are **blueprints for creating objects**. Think of them as templates:

```python
# Class = Blueprint
class Character:
    pass

# Objects = Instances created from blueprint
hero = Character()
villain = Character()
```

## Class Anatomy

```python
class Character:
    # Constructor - runs when creating new instance
    def __init__(self, name, health):
        self.name = name      # Instance attribute
        self.health = health  # Instance attribute
    
# Create instances
warrior = Character("Ragnar", 100)
mage = Character("Gandalf", 70)

print(warrior.name)    # "Ragnar"
print(mage.health)     # 70
```

## The `__init__` Method

- **Constructor** - special method that runs automatically
- **First parameter is always `self`** - refers to the instance
- Sets up initial attribute values
- Called when you create a new object

## The `self` Parameter

`self` refers to the instance being created/used:

```python
class Dog:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name  # self.name is instance attribute

dog1 = Dog("Rex")
dog2 = Dog("Buddy")

print(dog1.name)  # "Rex" - dog1's name
print(dog2.name)  # "Buddy" - dog2's name
```

## Multiple Attributes

Classes can have many attributes:

```python
class Character:
    def __init__(self, name, health, mana, level, experience):
        self.name = name
        self.health = health
        self.mana = mana
        self.level = level
        self.experience = experience

hero = Character("Hero", 100, 50, 1, 0)
```

## Your Quest

The Academy has a basic `Character` class, but it's missing crucial attributes!

Expand the class to include:
- Name
- Health (HP)
- Mana (MP)
- Level
- Experience (XP)
- Character class (warrior/mage/rogue)

Then create three different characters with different attributes!

‚öîÔ∏è Build the foundation for an RPG character system!

solutionCode:
# Character System - Class Expansion Solution

class Character:
    def __init__(self, name, health, mana, level, experience, char_class):
        self.name = name
        self.health = health
        self.mana = mana
        self.level = level
        self.experience = experience
        self.char_class = char_class

print("=== Character Creation ===")
print()

warrior = Character("Ragnar", 120, 30, 5, 450, "warrior")
mage = Character("Gandalf", 70, 150, 7, 890, "mage")
rogue = Character("Shadow", 90, 60, 6, 620, "rogue")

print(f"Warrior: {warrior.name}")
print(f"  HP: {warrior.health} | MP: {warrior.mana}")
print(f"  Level: {warrior.level} | XP: {warrior.experience}")
print(f"  Class: {warrior.char_class}")
print()

print(f"Mage: {mage.name}")
print(f"  HP: {mage.health} | MP: {mage.mana}")
print(f"  Level: {mage.level} | XP: {mage.experience}")
print(f"  Class: {mage.char_class}")
print()

print(f"Rogue: {rogue.name}")
print(f"  HP: {rogue.health} | MP: {rogue.mana}")
print(f"  Level: {rogue.level} | XP: {rogue.experience}")
print(f"  Class: {rogue.char_class}")
print()

print("Characters created successfully!")
hints: The __init__ method needs parameters for all attributes: def __init__(self, name, health, mana, level, experience, char_class)
Inside __init__, assign each parameter to self: self.health = health, self.mana = mana, etc.
Remember: the first parameter is ALWAYS self, then your custom parameters come after.
Create instances by passing all required values: Character("Name", 100, 50, 1, 0, "warrior")

Complete __init__ structure:
```python
def __init__(self, name, health, mana, level, experience, char_class):
    self.name = name
    self.health = health
    self.mana = mana
    self.level = level
    self.experience = experience
    self.char_class = char_class
```

learningObjectives: Understand what classes are and why they're useful
Use self to create instance attributes
Create multiple instances from the same class
Access instance attributes using dot notation

commonMistakes.explanation: Every method in a class must have 'self' as the first parameter, even __init__!

commonMistakes.mistake: Not using self when setting attributes
commonMistakes.explanation: Use self.attribute_name to create instance attributes. Just 'name = name' creates a local variable, not an attribute.

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to pass all arguments when creating instance
commonMistakes.explanation: If __init__ requires 6 parameters (plus self), you must pass 6 arguments when creating the object.
